posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked:
We are using the CTRE Swerve with pathplanner example and we’re running into a problem where our robot is generally following the path that it is supposed to but at the beggining and end it is and making loud cracking noises. We don’t have the modules lubricated so we expect that but throughout it appears like the swerve motors are jittering while they follow the path. It is most noticeable at the beginning and end of the auto that we are running. Our specs are MK4N modules with all ctre components (Kraken x60s, pigeon 2, CANCoders).

One other thing that we also observed was now (after 2/3 test runs with the problem stated above), the robot is now not following any path after auto and instead only looks jiggle in place momentarily before stopping.

If anyone has any idea of what the issue is or could be we would greatly appreciate the help.

posts.name: Aiden Keegan
posts.cooked: the jitter sounds to me like your p gain is high. Have you tuned your holonomic and module gains? The documentation for the advantagekit template project has some pretty good instructions on how to do this, even if you’re using the ctre base.

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: We’ve tried PID Tuning the values using yagsl and advantage scope. Would it be the same process?

posts.name: Aiden Keegan
posts.cooked: Im not too familiar with yagsl but id be willing to bet that its at least very similar

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked:
We’re trying to tune the pid values but no matter what we do we can’t get the measuredState to get anywhere close to the targetState. We have the p value set to 100 (if we set it to anything above that the motors start to jitter without any input). From what I understand, you are supposed to set every value to 0 until the measured state is around the targetState but the measuredState starts off way below the target. In this example, it is off by 6, but we I regenerated the tunerConstants and now the difference between the measured and target is 60. After rebooting the robot, the difference between the measured and target states is now ~15 (with the measured state being a greater value now). Screenshot (2) 1920×1080 209 KB

Screenshot (2) 1920×1080 209 KB

Screenshot (2) 1920×1080 209 KB

Here is what our pid values look like currently. (We are only changing the steer gains because our drive gains are fine). When we increase the I gain, it doesn’t close the gap between the two like we believe that it should.

posts.name: Troy Maurer
posts.cooked: Hello, Just wondering if you have tried driving the swerve around? It could help narrow the problem down significantly. If the robot drives perfectly, then it is likely an issue with Pathplanner or AutoBuilder. If the robot does not drive perfectly, then it is likely an issue with the swerve modules and tuning.

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: Our main issue when we are driving around, our swerve modules make a cracking noise when we try to drive at 45 degree angles (or when the steer motors are changing direction while driving). This happens when we are both on blocks and driving on the ground and our pid gains seem to make the actual and target states align now. I’ll attach a video but it seems like the motors may be jittering whenever there is input causing the steer motors to move.

posts.name: Troy Maurer
posts.cooked: Unfortunately, that means that it is a swerve tuning issue, and since my team doesn’t use yagsl, I am not sure what would be causing the modules to do that. From the video, the modules in the beginning appeared to behave normally. That was until, like you said, a certain turn angle was reached and the modules started making the cracking noise. Since it only breaks when the wheels are at an angle there could be something wrong with the angle calculation logic? Honestly though, I have no idea what the problem is.

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: We’re having this problem on the ctre swerve example code from the phoenix 6 example. If your team uses that one, do you know where we would be able to access the calculation logic to make changes to it because we are (completely) lost in navigating the code

posts.name: Troy Maurer
posts.cooked:
I found an older post about the CTRE swerve code from a user named kreeve.

Plot your (desired and actual) module speeds/angles in advantage scope. If your speeds are significantly off you might want to switch to closed loop

Bind a button to a “drive straight at constant speed” request, take out joysticks from the equation. I think the default command swerve generated code has it as a DPad button

It would seem that his first point about advantage scope would match your situation exactly. If you don’t use a closed loop controller, you could try that (It sounds like the default controller for CTRE swerve is open loop).

link_counts.title: Drift Issues with CTRE Swerve Code (Need Pro?)

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked:
From what I’m seeing, the ctre uses a closed loop controller. We see this in RobotContainer in the example

But there is no closed loop option for this. In our tuner Constants file, we see this

and I think that this is is more of what it is saying to switch but it is closed loop already

posts.name: Troy Maurer
posts.cooked: I did a bit more reading and you are right, the steer gains already use closed loop control. The drive gains use open loop control, but changing that wouldn’t help you solve your problem. However, you also noted that the PID gains now correctly match the target and measured state, which means that the problem should be solved except for some PID tuning. I would start with tuning .withkP as 100 seems a little high. Then again, I have heard that the steerGains kP can get surprisingly high before causing issues.

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: When using advantage scope, our pid gains seem to match it almost exactly after a little more tuning. At this point I have no clue what it could be or if it’s even an issue with the example code. I would like to run the sysID (because that seems like the better way to tune them) but I am currently waiting for us to get a big enough space to run the routine. From what it sounds like, do you believe that it could be an issue outside of the programming side?

posts.name: Troy Maurer
posts.cooked: Did you eventually get the modules lubricated? Because that could be it. Unexpected friction could be a driver of the issue.

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: We applied grease to all of the modules after the first couple of tests and still no luck

posts.name: Troy Maurer
posts.cooked: Check your controller output. Perhaps there is an inconsistent reading from your controller causing it to rapidly command the drive to swap from 2 close angles. Though this wouldn’t explain the problem in autonomous.

posts.name: 5089 Robonerds
posts.cooked: I tried changing the controller and it did the exact same problem. Our controller output looked fine with no rapid changing in numbers

posts.name: Troy Maurer
posts.cooked: Then, unfortunately, I am just as lost as you are. Sorry I couldn’t help you figure it out.
